article.title: VLA-COSMOS 3GHz Large Project: The infrared-radio correlation of star-forming galaxies and AGN to $z\lesssim 6$

multiple_choice_question.text: What percentage of objects in the jointly-selected sample are detected in both the radio and infrared?
What is the approximate median redshift of the star-forming population in the jointly-selected sample?
What is the typical 3 GHz to 1.4 GHz spectral index (α<sub>1.4GHz</sub>) of the star-forming population at z < 2.0?
What is the purpose of convolving the 3 GHz map to different resolutions?
choices: To increase the signal-to-noise ratio of point sources.
To detect extended and diffuse radio emission that might be missed at higher resolution.
To improve the astrometric accuracy of the radio sources.
To create a visually appealing image of the radio sky.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the presence of arrows in Figure 6 represent?
choices: Upper or lower limits on either infrared or radio luminosity due to non-detections.
The spectral index of the radio emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which dataset has the highest sensitivity (lowest flux limit) for detecting galaxies at z ~ 2?
choices: They all have similar sensitivities at that redshift.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding regarding the IRRC (q<sub>TIR</sub>) of star-forming galaxies with increasing redshift?
choices: q<sub>TIR</sub> shows a strong, non-linear decrease.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Formula (1), what does D<sub>L</sub> represent?
choices: The angular diameter distance to the object.
The luminosity distance to the object.
The spectral index of the radio emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (5) provides a redshift-dependent relation between SFR and which other quantity?
